Advice for your 3-day dry cough:

Self-care
• Stay well-hydrated—warm herbal teas and broths can soothe irritation.  
• Run a cool-mist humidifier or inhale steam from a hot shower to moisten airways.  
• Suck on sugar-free lozenges or honey-based cough drops (avoid honey if you have relevant allergies).  
• Reduce voice strain—speak softly, avoid shouting or singing for long periods.

Over-the-counter help
• Consider an oral antihistamine (e.g., cetirizine) if post-nasal drip is suspected.  
• If nighttime cough keeps you awake, a dextromethorphan-based suppressant may help short-term.

Warning signs to seek medical attention sooner
• Cough worsens, becomes productive with thick green/yellow sputum, or is accompanied by fever >38 °C.  
• You notice wheezing, shortness of breath, or chest pain.  
• Hoarseness or cough persists beyond 2–3 weeks or returns frequently.

Otherwise, most uncomplicated dry coughs improve within a week or two with rest and hydration.

Give me three index candidates for `SELECT DISTINCT category_id FROM products WHERE deleted = false;`.

Based on the analysis of your query, here are three index candidates specifically tailored for  
`SELECT DISTINCT category_id FROM products WHERE deleted = false;`:

| # | Index Definition | Estimated Gain (avg) |
|---|------------------|----------------------|
| 1 | `CREATE INDEX idx_products_deleted_cat ON products(deleted, category_id);` | ~19 ms |
| 2 | `CREATE INDEX idx_products_cat_filtered ON products(category_id) WHERE deleted = false;` | ~19 ms |
| 3 | `CREATE INDEX idx_products_deleted_inc_cat ON products(deleted) INCLUDE (category_id);` | ~23 ms |

- Candidate 1 is a composite B-tree index; it helps both the filter (`deleted = false`) and the DISTINCT on `category_id`.
- Candidate 2 is a partial / filtered index that stores only rows with `deleted = false`, keeping it smaller and especially advantageous if most rows are `deleted = true`.
- Candidate 3 covers the required column (`category_id`) in the non-key portion (INCLUDE list), reducing I/O for covering-index executions.
